Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Maximizing Mentor Effectiveness In Increasing Student Interest And Success In STEM: An Empirical Approach Employing Robotics Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This collaborative project is conducting a research study to delineate the effective components of mentoring for underrepresented and non-underrepresented students in STEM, utilizing a robotics educational program. To understand STEM expectations of success and interests in pursuing STEM careers, it is imperative to understand the achievement-related choices people make when deciding what areas to study and what careers to pursue. If mentoring is to be used to its fullest capacity in increasing students' interest in pursuing STEM careers, it is imperative to delineate what type of mentoring is most effective in increasing STEM self-efficacy and achievement-related choices. This proposal is addressing the following research questions: "Can a general 'best practices' mentoring approach be effective or is a specific self-efficacy approach needed? Is a combination of the two approaches optimal? In addition, does student ethnicity moderate the impact of the mentoring approaches?" Forty-eight teams of approximately 480 male and female participants represent middle school classes that have not previously participated in robotics or a similar STEM activity. Team mentors are divided into those receiving best-practices mentor training, self-efficacy mentor training, a combination, and no mentor training (control group). All teams participate in a Botball regional robotics competition organized by the KISS Institute for Practical Robotics. Employing a mixed factorial design, the study examines three types of mentor training for their impact on STEM self-efficacy and expectations of success and/or STEM achievement-related choices. The results along with the feedback from mentors will be used to develop a mentor-training package that could be used in all robotics programs and be generalized to other similar STEM activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of the research was to investigate factors that might increase middle school student self-efficacy (belief about his/her abilities) and achievement-related choices (pursuits of certain studies and careers) in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM). Two studies were conducted: a mentor study and a context study. The mentor study examined what type of mentoring approach was most effective in increasing student STEM self-efficacy and achievement-related choices, and also if student race moderated the effectiveness of the mentoring approaches. The context study investigated differences in the impacts of robotics activities in physical vs. social contexts and their respective effects on factors that contribute to student achievement-related choices in STEM.

In the mentor study, teachers were trained in four different mentoring techniques to support 7th and 8th grade African American, Caucasian, and Latino/Latina students’ participation in the Botball Educational Robotics Program (www.botball.org). The results indicate that students who perceived their teachers as being highly engaged in their own STEM activities showed increased beliefs about their own abilities in STEM, and an increased interest in pursuing STEM studies and careers. Neither student gender nor minority status was found to influence changes in STEM self-efficacy or achievement-related choices; however, African American and Latino/Latina students reported lower beliefs about about their abilities in STEM than Caucasian students as they were first entering into the STEM activities of the project. These results illustrate a barrier to entry into STEM for students of minority status, and should be a focus of future work in supporting minority students in STEM.

The context study integrated robotics activities in both physical contexts (e.g., interacting with objects) and social contexts (e.g., interacting with people) into formal middle school STEM curricula, and their respective effects on the interest and experiences of students in STEM-related activities. In both physical robotics and social robotics activities, the STEM principles (content) was the same, but the problems and applications (context) to which they were applied were different. Overall, the results highlight the positive impact of general robotics-related activities in supporting student interest and participation in STEM, and suggest that social robotics activities can serve as a powerful alternative to physical robotics activities in promoting STEM self-efficacy and STEM achievement-related choices in students at ages of significant social development (e.g., middle school).

The scientific merit of this work is in the resulting guidelines for effective mentoring strategies, as well as an understanding of why they are effective. The training is directly useful for any educational robotics program and has been disseminated accordingly. Because the studies provided insights into both the “how” and “why” of effective STEM mentoring, the robotics mentor training materials developed can be modified for and have broader impacts within any STEM activity.

The work on this project was made possible with collaborators from Southern Illinois University Edwardsville (SIUE) who led the effort, as well as with key partners at the KISS Institute for Practical Robotics (KIPR) who organized the Botball Educational Robotics Program and connected the project with its vast network of teachers and students. The work on this project also included the involvement of undergraduate students, who were engaged in hardware, software, and curriculum development as a means of STEM training.
